Having studied General Relativity with a professor whose's speciality was general relativity, I was taught some of the many misconceptions. 

Einstein explained that acceleration is indistinguishable from gravity in a LIMITED reference frame.  They are NOT equivalent.  Consider the often used thought experiment of an elevator falling towards earth.  The persons within the elevator are in free fall, so it seems like the acceleration perfectly balances out the gravitational field.  Thus the common belief that the acceleration is equivalent to a gravitational field.  But, place two balls as far apart as you can within the elevator.  As the elevator approaches earth, the balls are attracted to the centre of the earth, so they move in two lines that are not exactly parallel.  These two balls will approach each other more rapidly than can be defined by the gravitational force between them.  Given enough precision, enough time, a large enough elevator ( so the balls are VERY far apart), it would be possible to discern the actual existence of a gravitational object, and realize that you must be in free-fall, and are accelerating.  

Mathematically, the curvature of space in an accelerating reference frame can be reworked to an 'flat' space-time, whereas this cannot be done for a gravitational field.
